projects.title: Faces to Graves
projects.description: Faces to graves is a collaboration project between National Liberation Museum in Nijmegen and Master students at the Erasmus University Rotterdam. The project entails us to research and discover native Canadian soldiers who are buried at the Groesbeek Canadian memorial cemetery in Nijmegen. The findings will be composed into biographies and will be displayed at the museum

projects.title: A soldier’s truth: How diaries portray the reality of the war in    the Middle Eastern Theatre during World War I
projects.description:
A soldiers truth is an in-depth analysis of British and Commonwealth soldier diaries of the war front accounts in the Middle Eastern Theater World War I. The core aim of this thesis is to examine the diaries of the soldiers who fought in the Middle East and how accurate was their reports. These accounts will then be matched with news reports from newspapers such as the Daily Mail and/or The Times to see was there any significant differences. Additionally, theoretical concepts such as the "timing narrative", "collective memory" and "censorship" will be applied to get a greater understanding of how diaries and newspapers were composed during the First World War. From here, one should discover was there any misleading of news reports and why? or were soldier diaries providing inaccurate accounts due to the conditions they suffered (lack of food, sleep and illness)?
My tasks and research include:
1: Searching through databases from the British museum to locate soldier diaries.
2: Establishing a base of my findings of diaries from the British and Commonwealth soldiers.
3: Collecting newspapers from various sites to collaborate with my findings.
4: Collaborating with my supervisors with any updates of my research.
5: Extensive and in depth analysis on the use of 40 soldier diaries throughout the thesis.
6: Composing my findings into a 25'000 word dissertation.

Results: Facts on the British involvements differed between soldier diaries and newspapers in regards to British defeat at Gallipoli and Kut. The theories applied to newspapers suggest the information within newspapers were altered by the British government to keep morale up. However, the theories applied to soldier diaries suggest the information also contained biased or inaccurate accounts. This was due to fatigue, illness and the time period they had to compose their thoughts into writing.

projects.title: Digital Exhibition- Looking back on Limerick
projects.description: We obtained paintings of landmarks from artist Paul Grimes and putting together a presentation. We collaborated with Anne O Dwyer who gave us the paintings and also the niece of Paul Grimes. We also background information with each painting with its history and location. This project promoted the heritage history of Limerick and other landscapes around Limerick for the city of culture.

projects.title: The Weir Family History - Casebook Study: Origins, Migration and Journey - Cork Family History
projects.description: For this project, we were tasked to discover the family line of William Weir. We would browse through various websites like Family Search, Roots Ireland, Ancestry, Irish Census and Find My Past. We would search through various census birth records, marriage records, death records, military records to find missing family members from the family tree.This was important as it this would tell us where they were born, from and who they married. We would then piece the information together and write up a report on the findings.

projects.title: Duhallow ancestry- 'The Aldworths of Newmarket Court;Their influence on Duhallow and Beyond
projects.description: Our responsibility for this project was to obtain information on the history of Duhallow. This would include, browsing through the newspaper archives parliamentary papers and the University of Limerick libary for information. We had find out who were the Aldworth family, what influence they had on Newmarket Court and the area surrounding it. Other stories would include the Duhallow hounds. We would then put our collected information into a dropbox folder for Our boss, who would then deliver the information to the Duhallow heritage council.

projects.title: The work and Influences of Sebastian Vauban throughout the  seventeenth and eighteenth century.
projects.description:
This assignment was my Final Year Project for my bachelor's degree. The project was about Sebastian Vauban who was a French military engineer in the seventeenth century. The goal of this project was to create an analytical study of the work he did and see was he influential in the next century. This relates to infrastructure designs and military methods. I would compare maps of fortresses, cities and other engineers to see if there was any pattern to relate their work or style to Vauban.
An attachment of my FYP on Vauban can be found in the education sector under the University of Limerick.

profile_positions.description:
The project was creating a series of biographies of Canadian soldiers, who perished in the Netherlands in the Second World War. The findings were formatted into biographies. The biographies will be displayed through an exhibition at the museum in the future. The project was  co-operated with my superiors at the National Liberation Museum in Nijmegen. The work was conducted with a team of four. The tasks are outlined as followed.

Project Managed the following:
1: Creating a database. Formulating biographies of the Canadian soldier's
2: Intense research from archives and databases both in the Netherlands and Canada.
3: Co-operating with my superiors with the progress we made.

profile_positions.title: Student Internship

profile_positions.description: Pueblo Ingles is a camp where Spanish teens come and improve their English by integrating with Anglo teens from around the world. My tasks included looking after a group of teens from various countries around the world. I would create activities for the teens in order to assist in improving their English. I also had to work as a team member with other monitors in the camp in order to create stability and to make sure the camp was running smooth. This relates to taking night shifts and creating schedules so we would be organised. From this experience I learned valuable team coordination, time keeping and good social interaction amongst the teens, my work colleagues and bosses.
profile_positions.title: Monitor/Councilor

profile_positions.description:
Took part  in a Co-operative placement during my second year of studies. I worked with two other students and Lorna Moloney, who organised the placement. We received training in cloud computing, Dropbox, Trello, Prezi and Citavi.  We were assigned projects on a monthly basis. The projects are as followed. 
1:  The Digital exhibition. In this project our task was to put together a slide show which included painted pictures of areas in Limerick and Clare. We also researched the background of the paintings and then put the slide show out on the culture vultures Facebook page.
2: Duhallow project in Newmarket. Our task was to research stories of Duhallow on various newspapers throughout the years. These stories include the Duhallow hounds and the Aldworth family. We would put our findings on dropbox and send it to the Duhallow heritage council.
We also did advertisement and marketing on other projects. For the summer school we put of posters around the city of Limerick. We also promoted the school via Facebook and Twitter. 
For the Genealogy event we helped the organizer with the project in terms of marketing and promoting it.
3: Willie Weir Genealogy Project. The Willie Weir  project we researched his family history and put together a family tree for him. 
4: George Boole Genealogy Project. For George Boole our task was to find living descendants and make a list of them for the 200th anniversary of his birth.
